title: Collisions - different darts hit a hanging sphere

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A dart is launched toward the center of a sphere that hangs from the ceiling by a string, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The masses of the dart and the sphere are <math alttext="m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="5 m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math>, respectively, and the center of the sphere is initially a distance <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math> below the ceiling. The dart is traveling horizontally with a speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> immediately before it collides and sticks to the sphere. After the collision, the dart-sphere system swings upward on the string until its center of mass reaches a maximum vertical height <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> above its position at the time of the collision. The dart is initially traveling fast enough that it can be considered to be traveling horizontally before colliding with the sphere. (a)i. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the total kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub d s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">‐</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></msub></math> of the dart-sphere system as a function of time over the entire range shown on the time axis. The collision occurs at time <math alttext="t sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math>, and the system reaches its maximum height at time <math alttext="t sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A dart is launched toward the center of a sphere that hangs from the ceiling by a string, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The masses of the dart and the sphere are <math alttext="m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="5 m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math>, respectively, and the center of the sphere is initially a distance <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math> below the ceiling. The dart is traveling horizontally with a speed <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> immediately before it collides and sticks to the sphere. After the collision, the dart-sphere system swings upward on the string until its center of mass reaches a maximum vertical height <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> above its position at the time of the collision. The dart is initially traveling fast enough that it can be considered to be traveling horizontally before colliding with the sphere. (a)i. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the total kinetic energy <math alttext="K sub d s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">‐</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow></msub></math> of the dart-sphere system as a function of time over the entire range shown on the time axis. The collision occurs at time <math alttext="t sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math>, and the system reaches its maximum height at time <math alttext="t sub max" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>t</mi><mi>max</mi></msub></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the speed <math alttext="v sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></msub></math> of the dart-sphere system immediately after the dart collides with the sphere. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

iii. Derive an expression for the maximum vertical height <math alttext="delta y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>y</mi></math> of the dart-sphere system above its position at the time of the collision. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>ℓ</mo></math>, <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

Three more darts are launched, one at a time, at the sphere. Each dart has the same mass <math alttext="m sub d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mtext>d</mtext></msub></math> and collides with the sphere with the same horizontal velocity <math alttext="v sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> to the right, with the sphere initially hanging at rest on the string.The darts are made of different materials, however, and each behaves differently when it collides with the sphere, as follows.Stick dart: This dart sticks to the sphere and remains stuck in the sphere. After the collision, the dart-sphere system swings to a maximum height <math alttext="delta y sub stick" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>stick</mi></msub></math>.Bounce dart: This dart bounces off the sphere and then moves backward, to the left. After the collision, the sphere swings to a maximum height <math alttext="delta y sub bounce" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>bounce</mi></msub></math>.Through dart: This dart passes all the way through the sphere and continues traveling away to the right. After the collision, the sphere swings to a maximum height <math alttext="delta y sub through" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mi>y</mi><mi>through</mi></msub></math>.(b) Indicate which of the three darts results in the greatest maximum height for the sphere. Justify your answer.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
